trial_identification.studytitle: Efficacy of Nasojejunal Enteral Feeding in Critically Ill Patients.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Efficacy of Nasojejunal Enteral Feeding in Critically Ill Patients.

interventions.interventions:
Treatment: surgery - Nasojejunal feeding
No Intervention: Standard Care - Patients will receive enteral nutrition via a nasogastric tube as per standard feeding regime
Active Comparator: Nasojejunal Arm - Patient will receive feeding via a nasojejunal feeding tube
Treatment: surgery: Nasojejunal feeding

primaryOutcome.timepoint: participants will be followed until death, discharge from ICU, commencement of oral or parental nutrition or 28 days post ICU admission

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 1. To determine the incidence of complications with enteral feeding via nasogastric and nasojejunal routes.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: participants will be followed until death, discharge from ICU, commencement of parental or oral nutrition or 28 days post ICU admission.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: 2. To assess the efficacy of current strategies for optimising enteral feeding efficacy.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: participants will be followed until death, discharge from ICU commencement of oral or parental nutrition,or 28 days post ICU admission.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
1. Adult patients (18years or over) admitted to the ICU with an expected stay of more than 48 hours.
2. Patients commenced on enteral feeding via a nasogastric tube who fail to tolerate gastric feeding due to excessive gastric aspirate volumes.
3. Patients who consent or if the patient is incompetent, the next of kin, who consent, to inclusion in the study.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria:
1. patients less than 18 years of age.
2. Patients with known allergy to promotility agents, metoclopramide or erythromycin.
3. Patients with a contra indication to nasojejunal feeding. -

recruitment.hospital: Intensive Care Unit, Royal Melbourne Hospital, Grattan Street - Parkville

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
The purpose of this study is to determine if naso-jejunal feeding (feeding beyond the stomach) improves the efficacy of enteral feeding (feeding into the gut) in critically ill patients.
The study hypothesis is that in patients who fail to establish enteral feeding via the nasogastric route, introduction of nasojejunal feeding will lead to more effective enteral feeding than the current regime involving staged introduction of promotility agents.

contact.name: Megan Robertson
contact.address: Intensive Care Unit, Royal Melbourne Hospital
